Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for Students to Attend 2019 DAMOP Conference, May 27-31, 2019 in Milwaukee, WI.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides travel support for student participation in the 2019 meeting of the APS Division of Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics. The conference program includes many of the research topics central to Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics and Quantum Information Science. The support of students through this award makes a substantial contribution to the education and training of future scientists. Students who graduate with a background in atomic, molecular, and optical physics acquire a broad range of knowledge and skills that enable them to contribute to progress in many areas of science and technology.

The meeting is scheduled to be held in Milwaukee, Wisconsin May 27 through May 31, 2019. It offers an opportunity for students to present their research results and to interact with senior scientists primarily from the United States, but also the broader international community. Support is provided only for US students (students enrolled in US universities).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award entitled "Travel Support for Students to Attend 2019 DAMOP" provided travel support for graduate students to attend the annual DAMOP conference in Milwaukee, WI, May 27-31, 2019. The conference attracted around 1000 scientists of all career stages (undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, staff scientists, faculty, representatives from industry). The conference featured a mix of plenary talks, parallel sessions, and several early evening poster sessions. The parallel sessions were divided into invited talks (30 minutes) and contributed talks (12 minutes). Despite of its comparatively large size, the DAMOP conference series is known for providing many networking opportunities during the coffee breaks and during the poster session. Because of this, the attendance of DAMOP is extremely vital to young researchers in atomic, molecular, and optical physics. The student travel support made available through this award played a crucial role in allowing students to attend the conference. Many of these students would not have been able to attend the conference without the support provided through this award. The graduate student symposium, which was held on the day prior to the start of the official conference program, was attended by over 100 graduate students. It was a great success and hugely enriched the conference experience of the students who attended.


Last Modified: 02/08/2020
Modified by: Doerte Blume
